title: Very well done
text: I went here many years ago and they've certainly upped their game for the tourists! The displays are superb and informative, the lay out and way to walk around the complex easy to follow and they are magnificent testimony to Roman ingenuity as many of their drains are in use and working today. The audio devices (included in the ticket price) are extremely comprehensive in their descriptions. A family ticket for 2 adults and 2 children is around £43 and allow around 2-3 hours to explore. Regular footwear is all you'll need, though some surfaces are uneven.

title: Absolutely delicious
text: We loved this shop - free tastings are available and it is absolutely THE best cheddar we have ever tasted. A large round, around 600grams will set you back £16.99, but so worth it. The cheese is actually matured in Gough's cave so you definitely know you're getting true local produce!

title: Something for everyone
text: These caves have really been marketed up heaps since I was last here. The tickets you purchase gets you into the whole complex: Gough's Cave, Dreamhunters Cox cave, the prehistory Museum and Jacobs Ladder. The Dreamhunters cave has a display every half hour on the hour and half hour mark. To be honest, this was the least enjoyable of the gorge experience. Flashy lights and a whole lot of nothing....Gough's Cave, however runs you through the history of the place and since we went around Christmas, has loads of Christmas displays throughout the cave. The prehistory museum was pretty brief, but covered most aspects of humanity from Cheddar Man's time (approx 10000 years ago). Jacobs ladder is accessed as you exit Cox's cave and at the top of the 274 steps you can elect to climb the tower with awesome views of the area and then do a walk across the gorge (allow 2 hours). You'll need to allow a full day if you want to experience everything. Parking is a premium and costs everywhere you go (around £5) while entry for a family (2 adults, 2 children) is around £60 and includes entry to all I've mentioned.

title: Worst service and coffee EVER
text: We thought it hard pressed to get a poor coffee anywhere in Italy, but this place wins hands down. The service is shocking and staff are rude. We ordered 2 capuccino and they were COLD. When we took them back it was like WE were the rude ones. They simply reheated the ones the made and flung them across the counter at us. Do yourselves a favour and eat at McDonalds. If I could give this place a zero rating, I would.

title: Best food in Italy!!
text: Okay, best food in Italy may be a slight overstatement, but the food is superb. It's rolls with filling of your choice and it's FRESH and FLAVOURFUL. The prices are moderately reasonable for a fancy sandwich - $6-10 euro, but the staff are very friendly and accommodating. Open long hours and definitely worth a visit if you're tired of the, frankly, very ordinary pasta found in restaurants around Italy.

title: One incredible view
text: Get there early or go there late for best photo opportunities. Crowds are often huge. Entrance to the Basilica is to the right hand side and free to see. The walk to the Vatican museum is the the direct right when looking at the square and Basilica.

title: Magnificent
text: There's not much that I can add to the thousand of reviews. This is singularly spectacular. The Sistene Chapel is down a couple of rows of stairs and is a quiet and reflective zone. There are actually bench seats provided along the sides of the chapel where you may sit and reflect on the magnificent artworks from Michaelangelo. Be advised that no photos or videos are permitted in the chapel.

title: Catholic church at its most decadent
text: This Basilica is both impressive and a bit sickening, exemplifying the hypocritical nature and incredible wealth and power of the Catholic church. The Basilica is HUGE and has dedicated prayer sections, but also manages to have a few areas whereby you need to pay to see (including the museum within the basilica...) Outside the Basilica, not more than 50-100m and on the path to the Vatican museum,you can find, any given day, beggars, many of whom are amputees. The Basilica itself is free, so don't be scammed by all the ticket sellers lurking, offering 'cheap' tickets to get inside the Basilica and queue jump - there is no such thing.

title: Incredible collection
text: The Vatican museum and Sistene Chapel is definitely something to see when in Rome if you can afford it. For Aussie or kiwi travellers book in your overtime because it's 17 euro to just get in. The collection of art is extensive, though, and they boast a huge Egyptian and Greek collection pilfered centuries ago, including a real mummy!! The art by Michaelangelo (Sistene Chapel)and other artists of the era are spectacular and well worth seeing though you're not allowed to photograph in the Sistene Chapel. The statues, Greek or Roman (Greek inspired) are unparalleled.

title: Another must see
text: The Spanish steps are easy to find and are a free attraction for the enthusiastic tourist! Grab a photo on the steps which were originally built for ease of access to the church above them. There are 135 steps and they've been restored many,any times since they were first built in the early 1700's!

title: May as well!
text: This is also included in your ticket price to the Colosseum and is worth the hike up. Believed to be Nero's garden area, it offers great views of the Colosseum and the forum.

title: Utterly superb
text: Do not miss this after you see the Colosseum - it's included in the ticket price. From Nero to Augustus, Romulus' and Caesar, this ruin covers everything. Allow yourself 3 hours at least to explore this ancient wonder and wear super comfortable shoes....the cobblestones are a killer after a long day! Be sure to check out the views from the palace and Nero's vineyard as the latter provides great photo opportunity of the Colosseum. You can just imagine how grandiose the whole scene would have been a couple of thousand years ago! Be aware, if you want to do the museum there or the palace tunnel, there are significant additional costs. 6 euro each for the museum and the same for the tunnel, which can add up for a family, making the initial ticket price almost 30 euro. Not worth it in my opinion and smacks of greed.

title: Beautiful
text: The Pantheon is spectacular. It has enjoyed many careers over the century and enjoys beautifully preserved architecture. Open long hours and accessible outside by night it is not to be missed. There's lots of good shopping around this precinct too, as well as some nice restaurants. It's also only 450m from the Trevi fountain so it's easy to combine the two!

title: Beautiful day and night
text: I highly recommend you visit this both day and night. It's not too far of a walk from the pantheon (450m) or the colosseum. It's always crowded, but people are quick once they take their photos. Throw a coin over your shoulder and make a wish! A beautiful spot showing off the vast water supply the ancient Romans enjoyed!

title: A must
text: If you're in Rome, the Colosseum is a must! Tickets are 16euro which includes entry to the forum. The history of the colosseum is rich and interesting - even it's name was not meant to be the Colosseum, named Amphitheatre Flavium originally, but because it was located near a statue of a colossus...the nickname stuck. Beware of rip off merchant's promising you queue jumps and the like. Tour guides also promise a full tour of all 3 sites around the Colosseum, but take your money and only pay for a group pass to the Colosseum,doing a runner at the end, so make sure if you book a tour, to be sure your ticket covers the forum too. There are men walking up and down the queues selling water and souvenirs at extremely inflated prices so beware. As well, scammers thrust bracelets and other bits of rubbish at you and then demand money. Do not stop for these people. Lastly, if you don't want to wait hours and hours in frustration in the entry queues, book your tickets in advance. When numbers in the colosseum reach 3000, the entry of further tourists comes to a virtual stand still. Wear comfy shoes and pack lots to drink, especially if you go in summer.

title: Great to experience
text: We decided this would be be the perfect wet day activity. If you're staying anywhere near the train station, it's only a short walk, approximately 1km to Napoli Sotterranea. English speaking tours are conducted every hour on the hour and groups are taken in groups of about 60-65. The tour costs 10euro and lasts for 1.5 hours exactly. Be aware the front of house people taking payment are rude and angry, getting short and annoyed with tourists who are expected to queue in a tiny, stuffy area which would comfortably accommodate 20 people, NOT 60. The rules change depending upon which minute you show up. Pre-payment required prior to the tour, next minute, pay as you begin....who knows. The tour guides are nicer than the front of house people and somewhat knowledgeable on the topic they're presenting, though know very little actual fact about Italy's role in WWII and their allegiance to Germany and swapping to the allied forces side! The underground tour was interesting in that it was Greek ingenuity that saw 400km of aquaduct constructed to supply hundreds of thousands of Italians with potable water. The tour includes a walk through very narrow aquaduct tunnels so I don't recommend this if you're claustrophobic and obviously, no bulky bags or backpacks.Naturally, in Italy, there are many, many stairs to climb, so wear comfortable shoes. It gets very hot and stuffy down there, so wear layers that you can easily take off. The tour also incorporates a 30 second church walk through with zero explanation (why even bother?) and the Roman theatre that has been built over with 40 odd houses, but discovered 8 years ago and partially excavated those areas accessible or bought off residents. They rush people through and often several groups end up in the same place making it impossible to hear the information given by your guide. The whole process is executed poorly and it feels like they just want your money and care little about your experience. However, it's a worthwhile diversion and history lesson if you don't mind the utterly rude staff who seem like they'd rather be anywhere than where they are.

title: Best pizza in Italy
text: This place is the bomb for pizza. Dine in or takeaway, service is fast and efficient, staff nice (albeit flat out) and prices reasonable. Wha more could you ask for?
place: Da Donato dal 1956 Antica Trattoria e Pizzeria

title: Incredible service
text: We booked this on Expedia and we're thrilled with this gorgeous hotel. The staff were incredible - went above and beyond, especially Lalit (multi lingual and all-around awesome). Breakfast was included which was incredible with a massive selection of foods it kick started our days beautifully. Our room, while small, was spotlessly clean. There is also a key lockable safe box in the rooms. There is no elevator so bring your muscles to lug your cases up the steps if you're an international traveller. The entrance is one of the most charming in all of Venice and the foyer is welcoming and charming. The staff make this hotel utterly worthwhile and they are knowledgeable and give good tips on how to avoid being ripped off by greedy businesses. Highly recommend this hotel.

title: Escape the crowds
text: After spending 2 days in the total hustle and bustle of Venice tourist hotspots, it was a refreshing relief to escape to the Ghetto. Most locals live around here and this is evidenced by the markedly cheaper shops and restaurants. We ate one of our best meals along a canal and it cost 17 euro for both of us!! The buildings are older and the bridges less ornate, but it is easy to access on foot and well worth a stroll through if you want some peace and good value dining.

title: Wealth of the Catholic Church at its finest
text: I will never forget the first time I went here many years ago. Staff were hitting beggars with sticks to get off the Basilica steps. There are no beggars in sight today. The Basilica has limited opening hours and all photos and video are strictly forbidden and the staff take their jobs VERY seriously so don't think you can sneak one undetected! Saturday's they close at 1pm and reopen around 2.30pm for a very limited time, but are not open to the public at all on Sundays. The Basilica roof is multi-domed and utterly magnificent. The acoustics are also something to hear! Right on one side of the San Marco square and in front of Doges Palace, it's hard to miss! The wealth of the Catholic church is perfectly exemplified here - worth seeing even if you are adding to their coffers!

title: A great photo op
text: Another freebie if you're willing to leg it. Going via water is a bit more pricey, though you can share a gondola ride with 5 others for around 30euro for 20min...The bridge does get very congested so patience to get that plum photo is required! Worth it though!

title: A must see in Venice
text: Of course you must visit San Marco! If you go early morning, take gum boots because the whole square gets flooded and access is only via planks which get very congested and move slowly. The water clears around 11-12midday. This also houses the very ritzy shopping precinct. Be aware that if you sit anywhere around the square for any form of refreshment or food, you will pay an absolute premium. Some places charge a 6euro cover charge just to walk in! The souvenirs and shops along here (near St Mark's Basilica) are also much more expensive than further along, so be aware of this too.

title: Gorgeous
text: The Grand Canal is just that: Grand. The largest of the canals in Venice, it is constantly buzzing with activity. Great photo opportunities abound as it is one of the few things in Venice that costs nothing! If you feel like a meal/coffee - anything in fact, be aware that prices are very, very inflated along any of the waterways or major tourist hotspots and if you sit down, you can end up paying an easy 10euro just for a coffee. Restaurants along here also sting tourists huge service charges so before you eat or drink, ask. If they won't be transparent, move on!

title: Do not miss
text: Doges Palace is just behind St Mark's Basilica and if you have limited time, definitely put this on your must do list. With a rich history and a comprehensive artwork collection this is a superb experience for Venice. Cost is 25 euro per adult, and while expensive for those on a budget, I'd rather do this over any of the other things in Venice. The palace saw justice administration and senators wrote much of the law at the time. They claim to have very little trouble from the 13th century forward, but their extensive prison attached and their impressive execution rate, one would question their claims! The prison attached is included in the ticket price and is a sombre place indeed. As you go through look for the 'Bridge of Sighs,' so named because prisoners to be executed caught their last glimpse of Venice and sighed at the sight, on their way to their deaths. The artwork contained here is superb and the justice rooms are ornate, to say the least, built on the back of the massive silver resources of the time. The entire visit, if you read the exhibits and artwork would easily take 5 hours. There is lots of stair climbing and walking, so wear very comfortable shoes. There are very few places to sit and staff can be over the top and quite rude if you get too close to read the exhibits (one older woman was scolded for doing nothing wrong, but leaning in to read a description - the staff are very rude, proprietary and ungracious, especially considering they're at a major tourist Mecca and they hover, untrusting, around the entire palace in swarm numbers). There appears only one set of toilet amenities so there was always a very large queue at them when we walked past.

title: Always special
text: You just wouldn't come to Athens and not see this icon. Entry to the Acropolis is 10euro. The Parthenon is under constant repair so it is a real skill to get a photo without scaffolding in it. Worth a visit, nevertheless.

title: Cheeky Greeks
text: The Greeks really do well in getting the tourist dollars. This site, visible from the roads and right next door to Hadrian's Gate and free to wander through for ages, is now 4euro to get in now that they've fenced it off. There's not much to see other than the remains of the temple, but worth it if you haven't seen it up close. Wouldn't bother if you have - buy a good gyros instead with your hard earned cash.

title: Absolutely superb
text: This is located in the Agora ruin site and is spectacular. Well worth a visit. Allow about 3 hours to do the whole site. Entry is 6euro and they give you a map on entry to help with identification of the ruins!

title: Do not miss!!
text: This is always a highlight when visiting Athens. Entry is 6euro and no student cards from anywhere but Greece accepted, so other students expect to pay full price. You'll need several hours to explore this wonderful ruin which also includes the temple of Hephaestus. The displays are fantastic and the dioramas comprehensive of the area and its development which is visually chronicled from 500BC. You're your own boss as you wander around this ruin, so a guide book may help, although upon entry, you're given a numbered map to help orient yourself and understand the layout of the ancient community. Absolutely well worth a visit - better than the Acropolis site in our opinion and a stand out favourite. Allow 3 hours to do the site justice and see it well.

title: Worth a visit if you have time.
text: This museum is ok,but nothing compared to the British collection on display in London, of Greek artefacts. In order to see this museum, you have to pay another 5euro (no non EU student cards accepted). The museum is nice and modern with a nice outlay of the few artefacts on display. The absolute highlight is the ancient houses they're excavating/have excavated underneath the museum. This is far more interesting and worthwhile than the museum itself. If you're pushed for time, I'd say see something more worthwhile. If you have plenty of time, worth a visit!

title: Worth a visit
text: If you have a spare half hour,duck over to the parthenaic stadium. Easy to walk to from pretty much anywhere in Athens. Again, have your wallet at the ready - 5euro each. The museum is included, but it's small and you could probably see the whole thing in 10min including reading. Built in the 1800's, it's not exactly a ruin, but good to take a look at.

title: Majestic
text: The Acropolis still sits majestically above Athens. If you want to see this with minimal traffic, do so early in the morning. We arrived around 8.45am and there was very few out and about at this time. Tickets just for the Acropolis are 10euro and they do not accept non EU students despite having a student card. This does NOT include entry to the museum. The sites remain unchanged with workmen everywhere and many areas cordoned off. The scaffolding is still everywhere and it remains unchanged over 25 years of visiting this site (do the restorations already guys) and makes photography sans scaffolding difficult. Very important women watch with eagle eyes over the rope boundaries, blowing whistles with glee if a hapless tourist wanders off a designated path. Make sure you see everything because if you exit the Acropolis you cannot use your ticket again and must buy another. The walk around the mountain is well worth it, with hidden gems signposted showing glimpses of the past magnificence this bustling acropolis was. Sites like the bronze forge, the well, Dionysius' theatre, the statue Grove etc are all there to see, but, again, scaffolding and repair works - understandable, but a very long process... definitely worth a visit, especially if you haven't been there before.

title: Poor at best
text: We decided to take this option to visit Delphi. First off, they do not accept students, with a valid student card, from anywhere but Greece,so any visiting students be prepared to pay adult fares. The bus, return, very expensive at 65.60euro for two. We were given our tickets with no instruction and the departure terminal was not on our tickets. After finding our terminal, we boarded the bus. It was filthy with smeared, greasy windows and rubbish jammed into the seat bins. The bus was late departing. The return trip was worse with the bus arriving 20min late for pick up at Delphi. The bus driver had the heater on for a 23deg day causing several customers to ask him to turn it off, to no avail. Everyone had to take off max amount of clothing and were sweating and almost passing out as temperatures in the bus got to near 40deg Celcius. Finally, a Greek native spoke very sternly to him to turn on air. We arrived over 30min late to terminal back in Athens. Horrid experience.

title: Best in Greece
text: This museum is included in the ticket price. The staff were the friendliest and most helpful we have encountered. The pieces on display are absolutely superb and, in my opinion, far superior to those of the Acropolis museum. Do not miss this!

title: Spectacular Scenery
text: Delphi is the place of the oracles where mortals would complete their odyssey to seek the wisdom from those oracle's at Delphi. It's pretty easy to get there and is roughly a 2 hour drive from Athens. Our suggestion is to avoid the bus at all costs and hire a car and drive yourself. There are 2 tolls for a car that total $5euro at our time of travel. The drive is easy (once you're out of the city) and clearly sign posted. Entry to Delphi ruins is 6euro, but they do not accept students from other countries so be prepared to pay adult prices for your students. The site has been modernised since I was last there and access to the stadium severely restricted so that you can only see it from a roped off distance which was disappointing for me (who had wandered intimately through the ruins (without touching or destroying) but somewhat understandable.) The Delphi museum adjacent to the ruins is absolutely fantastic and your ticket price covers entry here. This museum is even better than the Acropolis museum. After you see all this, head 800m down the hill and visit the temple of Athena which is absolutely superb. You can wander around the ruins intimately and they have been spectacularly and tastefully restored. There are dozens of food places and souvenir shops, but be prepared to pay a premium for all things since this is strictly a tourist Mecca. Allow a full day to incorporate the drive, ruins, museum, a bite to eat and a shop.

title: Great Value for all
text: We stayed here over the Australia Day long weekend and while all the other businesses were madly fleecing all the tourists an extra 15% on top of already expensive prices, the Girls at By the Sea were offering free DVD hire, all free equipment hire (and the range is extensive: bikes, laptops, eski's, umbrellas, gym equipment etc), free ice and the list goes on. The staff were friendly and patient, professional and accommodating. It was our anniversary, so we were given a lovely, congratulatory card and a bottle of champagne on arrival. The room we were allocated from our online booking was not reflected in any of the pictures on the website, but we're not really fussy - as long as we have somewhere to sleep. The room was, however, very clean and well equipped. Parking was quite a nightmare because there just wasn't enough spaces and the fit was very tight, even for our tiny hire car. I can't speak for all the rooms, but they were not sound proofed very well - we could easily hear conversation from the room next door and lots of back ground noise, making it hard to sleep at times and, of course, being woken very early. I wouldn't, however, hesitate to recommend this place, purely on the basis of location (walking distance to the main hub of Port Douglas) and the incredible staff employed here.
place: By The Sea Port Douglas Resort

title: Great sized meals
text: We ordered the barramundi and a grilled chicken burger. The barra came with chips and a basic salad, but the star of the dish was the amazing tartare sauce! The chicken burger was pretty big and also came with chips - ok, but chips were skinny and too overcooked (but they were pretty busy). We also ordered a steamed vegetable side and these were superb. We had two beers with our meal and the whole lot was $55, so pretty good value since we left feeling full and satisfied. Staff were friendly.

title: Choose this company for your Daintree cruise!
text: First up, i accidentally booked the wrong date and rang the company at 7pm. I could NOT believe it when the owner, Bruce, answered. I explained my mistake and he changed us across to our preferred date, no hassles. Now, we wanted to take a cruise down the Daintree in the hope of being lucky enough to see a few crocs. We understand that crocs don't appear because people want them to, and considering the time of year, we weren't holding our breath. But, we were very lucky and managed to see several - ranging from hatchling to adult. Our guide, Jayden, was knowledgeable about the area; crocs and the flora of the Daintree and skilled at manoeuvring the boat around so all could see from a good vantage point. Back in the shop, Ray was absolutely awesome - we stayed and had a great chat and he helped us with his knowledge of things to do heading up to Cape Tribulation. We honestly cannot fault this family run tour operation and the staff were simply amazing. One of our Daintree highlights.

title: Gorgeous...and yes, you can walk in.
text: We read loads of reviews about this because we weren't sure if we could walk to the gorge from the visitor centre. While walking in is discouraged by the visitor centre and the bus operators (!) the walk is very doable and easy. It's approx 2km to the gorge boardwalk, so would take around 15min for those of average fitness (lots and lots of people do walk it). The road does narrow in some spots, but no traffic apart from the tour buses have access, so they're easy to hear and avoid! Once there, the gorge walk is absolutely fabulous (wear suitable footwear - there's some steep and slippery sections). If you're travelling during the very humid season, pack your bathers because there's some gorgeous swimming spots where many go in for a refreshing dip! This was one of our highlights for this area! Allow yourself at least 4 hours to enjoy this spot!

title: Pretty spot and lovely staff
text: We thought we could choose our ice cream flavours here, but we understand that, more often or not, you can't. When we arrived, we were presented with the 4 flavours (tiny scoops in one small cup for 7.50AUD), but we didn't eat two of the flavours and weren't familiar with the other 2. Luckily for us, the staff member was very accommodating and gave us some substitute flavours. The ice cream was nice, but not mind blowing....however, the spot was very pretty and, as mentioned, the staff member who served us, lovely.

title: Very ordinary
text: If you like value for money and a decent sized serve, we'd recommend giving this place a miss. Rice is served in such small bowls and at 3.50 per serve is ludicrously poor value on top of more expensive- than -usual for basic Thai mains. The majority of their staff have little to no English Skills so ordering is done via pointing and gesturing. Glasses and cutlery were also dirty with stains not properly washed off.

title: Shocking value for lots of money
text: We visited here in a big group and ordered our food. A couple of us ordered a salad. Well, despite the ridiculous cost, you wouldn't mind so much if you were served something more than a small entree size meal. However, we weren't. The value for about 4 forks full of salad was atrocious. Luckily there's a hungry Jack's straight outside so you can actually get a filling meal that won't break the bank. Do yourselves a favour and give this place a big miss.

title: Best pies ever
text: My son and I detoured here for lunch upon a recommendation and we were so happy we did. The pies are homemade and they have a huge variety. The steak is chunky and very lean (no horrid blobs of fat or gristle) and the pastry is perfect. They also supply a variety of vegetarian - the penang curry pumpkin pie was delicious. They're not cheap, but okay for a treat!! Enjoy this shop if you happen to stumble into this sleepy little town.

title: Little Gem with something for everyone
text: This was a quick stop on our road trip, but turned out a delightful little stop. This is a cafe style place with a gorgeous little gift shop attached. I spoke with the owner, Theresa, for quite some time and she was absolutely lovely. The food and coffee was lovely and I bought a beautiful gift for my daughter. Prices were reasonable with some bargains for thebdoscerning shopper. If you're on a road trip and happen to see this place, pop in!

title: Fun way to learn about Seattle's waterfront past!
text: We were interested to try this experience and weren't disappointed. There aren't a huge amount of underground stops because the company is reliant on businesses allowing the tour company access and only 3 or 4 have allowed it. Nevertheless, the tourguides make good use of what they have and entertain their groups with knowledgeable and entertaining tales of Seattle from yester year. Lasting about an hour and a half, explore parts of the waterfront in groups of about 25 or 30. Guide's are pretty chill and allow those of us wishing to hang back to get good photos before moving on. They're open until 7pm during peak times and 6pm others. Suitable for children from the age of about 8 up, otherwise they may get bored or frightened. We had a 13 year old with us who loved it! You don't have to pre book, as walk-ins are accommodated on a first served basis. All the guides we experienced were funny, articulate and very knowledgeable! Good way to spend some time exploring and learning. Kids are 13 and under, otherwise it's adult prices -27usd each.

title: Alright for a short time
text: We always visit the Pike Markets when in Seattle, but try to limit our time here. Each year it seems to expand, but there's the usual vendors: food, flowers, seafood, souvenirs and small independent businesses cashing in on the tourists! Colourful and pungent, Pike Markets don't disappoint. We always visit the thrift shop right up the end and always leave with some incredibly good value stuff. This store is the hidden gem of the Pike market! There's a nice outside spot where you can eat the food and drinks you cannot resist from the market with nice views, especially when the sun is out! Allow a couple of hours to get through most of it and it's also free to wander through and suitable for all ages!

title: An Italian restaurant that can really cook amazing pasta!
text: This restaurant, I have learned, has been in business since the 1950's and it's easy to understand why. The food from entree, to salads, mains and dessert is incredible. The flavours are without par and they service is exceptional. Best of all, their pasta is cooked to el dente perfection. Even their bloody Mary's pack incredible punch and flavour. If you're ever in this neck of the woods, do yourself a favour and do not miss this place. Pop in and see Joan for a meal you will never forget. Prices are very reasonable and each table gets bread sticks, and a stack of bread to begin with.

title: Sensational staff and sensational food
text: We were four lost, hungry and exhausted travellers who stumbled upon this burger restaurant. We were greeted by an incredibly accommodating concierge, Brandon, who showed us to our table. Our serving person was Latoya and she was amazing; friendly, bubbly, funny and pre-emptive to our needs. So we have the staff covered and cannot fault them. We all ordered a burger and got bottomless sweet potato fries. Our food was delivered so quickly and was incredibly fresh and tasty. All in my travelling party agreed that we had not had a better meal. When Brandon clocked out, he joined us at our table and we all had a great night of laughter and fun. Honestly cannot fault this place and recommend it highly across all fronts.

title: Good, but way too expensive for what you get
text: We decided this would be our activity of choice in Skaguay, Alaska. We had to arrive at the train station in Skaguay 15min, or so, prior to departure. This we did, with the expected 12.45pm departure. However, we didn't leave until 1.05pm and since this is advertised as a 3 hour round trip, we were a bit disappointed that we were only on the trip for 2.5hours. The scenery, however, was gorgeous with snow capped peaks etc and the periodic commentary of Annie, the train your guide, was informative and interesting. The frustrating thing was the obvious cash grab of kitsch souvenirs whilst on the train (cap, DVD and 'bonus' magazine for usd20) which we found pretty bad since we'd already paid usd122 for this rail tour. So I'm sorry to say that while it was Good, it wasn't great and most certainly not worth the small fortune we forked out for the pleasure in our party of 12. Too late we learned that you can get a bus tour that offers the same route, PLUS, more for $35. Feeling ripped off with this train ride and won't do it again.

title: Overpriced, but good views!
text: While this spot offers excellent views and modern decor (being a brand new sprung up winery) one can't help but feel that this place caters to a select clientele. They (alomg with many other wineries in this area) charge a 'tasting' fee of $5, and the price of their wines compared to other wineries in the area are, frankly, laughable. Do yourself a favour and go where there are established wines and they don't try and gouge out your hip pocket to pay for their fancy building.

title: Just comfortable
text: Aside from being clean, this hotel is in need of major renovation. The carpet is unsecured leading from the bathroom to the room and a trip hazard. The bathrooms are tiny that you can barely manoeuvre around the toilet into the shower with the basin outside leaving no privacy for brushing teeth or anything. The beds are super comfy, but this is no solace whatsoever with the paper thin walls meaning you hear EVERY, and I mean EVERY sound. Therefore, if you value your sleep, give this place a wide berth.

title: Peaceful with views!
text: If you're leaving the Rockies my road and heading south, this is a great stop. They offer a beautiful, fresh buffet for dinner which is very good value. The rooms are enormous, fresh and clean and the beds comfortable with great views from ypur window. The breakfast provided is comprehensive. There is a casino where you can whottle away your spare change too and a lovely gift shop in the lobby. Cannot fault this resort.

title: Beautiful views
text: We did the Athabasca Glacier 'walk' and the views were spectacular. I would Not recommend the glacier walk though. It's expensive and for 100CAD you only get 15min on the glacier, barely allowing time to get a photo off! Instead, drive to the centre and do the walks there for free and get the same photos whilst protecting your hip pocket! There's a great little museum, giftshop and toilets there too.

title: Delicious and good value
text: We tried the famous buffalo stew and chilli. While not discernable different from beef, the meals were tasty and reasonably priced. The only criticism is that the meals aren't exactly huge. Staff were friendly and got meals out in a very timely manner.

title: Great spot
text: We were here overnight, but the hotel clean, beds were very comfortable and, like the name says, is a gateway into Vancouver. There's a courtesy bus that runs to and from the airport every 20 minutes. From the airport you can catch the train (buy an all day transport card for 10.75 at the hotel shop) and if you get off at Watergate station, its either a 20min walk to Stanley Park. Alternatively, you can catch the number 19 bus there. Plus, the outlet shops are only a 10min walk from the hotel or a few stops on the train. Of course, you need loads of time to fully explore Vancouver, but this a great day trip if you have limited time, or are on a tour. Breakfast is provided for those who choose and it's a full one with plenty of hot and cold food options. Staff are great and with the obvious proximity to the airport and the free shuttle, its a perfect spot to stay.
place: Pacific Gateway Hotel at Vancouver Airport

title: Great, fun night out
text: Most hotels in Vernon offer 'free' casino money if you sign up. We took the hotel up on its offer and went to the casino. Included was a 15% discount on food if you are there and there's a pretty good menu available if you choose to dine there. Staff at the casino are awesome - friendly and all with a great sense of humour. Even better if you can turn your free money into a small win!

title: Don't do Vegas without seeing this!
text: This was out second time in Vegas and we couldn't resist going back here. Not as modern as the strip, it can take you back to the 60's when Elvis and The Brat Pack made it famous. It has all the old hotels - The Golden Nugget and Main St (killer buffet here) and, of course Freemont St itself with so much going on all night! There's the zip line and the nightly LED screen lighting up the whole of Freemont street with a sensational music and light extravaganza! At one end, you have The Heart Attack grill where if you're over 350 pounds you eat free!! Up the other end are a plethora of souvenir shops and you cam routinely buy Vegas tees and other funny one from between usd$2-10. Food is super cheap and in mammoth proportions and if you pay for parking, you can get a refund/validation if you eat at any of the casino restaurants.

title: The staff were lovely!
text: As a couple who have travelled extensively, we were underwhelmed by the Naviti. This is definitely no 4 star resort. In saying that, however, the grounds immediately around the resort were immaculately kept and the staff were lovely. If you intend to go, pack all your essentials like sunscreen, hats and repellent because the shop in room 101 is extortionate with a bottle of water at $9! Supermarkets are plentiful and in Sigatoka we stocked up on water for 90cents for 1.5L bottles. We found the restaurants poor value for the prices they charged - categorically NOT on par with Australia, despite protestation of the Naviti gen mgr - and we were not told that there would be 3 additional taxes applied to everything upon checkout, including their new environmental levy. Rooms were very old and run down and basic patch up jobs evident. We can appreciate the location and how everything is on 'Fiji' time, but if you do want that touch of luxury and comfort, consider staying elsewhere. This seemed to be the consensus of other guests we spoke to whilst at the Naviti. We'd like to reiterate that the staff were lovely, but we just did not find value here.

title: Breathtakingly beautiful
text: We spent a glorious week in Yosemite and it was beautiful. We cannot fault the scenery or the plethora of scenic walks/hikes available. We did the Yosemite Valley walk which was around 9miles long, taking in spectacular views along the hike, not least the spectacular half dome. The half dome can be hiked, but you have to apply for a ballot. We, unfortunately, we're not successful this time. Down in the Valley, there is a courtesy bus that transports tourists around to several stops for free. We used this hop on/off bus often. From memory, there's about 17 stops. Cannot overstate the beauty of Yosemite. Just wish we had more time there!
